variant.question: Liveware - Liveware interaction is:

options.text: the interface between people.
the interface between humans and the environment.
involving considerations such as designing seats to fit the sitting characteristics of the human body.
the interaction between humans and the non-physical aspects of the system such as procedures.

variant.question: Trace elements should be obtained through

options.text: a balanced diet.
eating plenty of meat and vegetables.
dairy products and vegetables.
vitamin pills.

variant.question: In a commercial aircraft, the recognised source of a "Fume Event" is/are:

options.text: Contaminants entering the bleed air supply, used in most commercial aircraft to supply cabin pressurisation and air conditioning.
Chemicals from the toilets interacting with the air conditioning system.
Small leaks in the fuel system over time finding their way into the cabin wall materials via the re-fuelling gallery.
Leaking oil mixing with the fuel in the Fuel/Oil heat exchanger and resulting in toxic gas release.

variant.question:
The planning and anticipation of future actions and situations makes it possible to
1) create a precise reference framework.
2) avoid saturation of the cognitive system.
3) automate planned actions.
4) activate knowledge which is considered necessary for the period to come.The correct statements are
Which is an example of an error caused by liveware-hardware interface problems?

options.text: Switches, controls or displays with poor design.
Noise interference.
A procedures that is not user friendly.
Mental pressure.

variant.question:
What means can be used to combat human error?
1) Reducing error-prone mechanisms.
2) Improving the way in which error is taken into account in training.
3) Sanctions against the initiators of error.
4) Improving error detection techniques.The combination of correct statements is

What means can be used to combat human error?
1) Reducing error-prone mechanisms.
2) Improving the way in which error is taken into account in training.
3) Sanctions against the initiators of error.
4) Improving error detection techniques.
The combination of correct statements is:
What is the advantage to flight crew of planning and anticipation of future actions?

options.text: Enables the crew to create a precise reference framework, activate knowledge as necessary for the period to come and avoid saturation of the cognitive system.
Reduces the requirement to use applicable checklists and negates the adherence to Standard Operating Procedures.
Allows for better analysis of flight crew peparedness in the event of an accident/incident.
Achieves accurate prediction of future events thus enabling a more relevant response.

variant.question: Planning:

options.text: allows crew members to anticipate potential risky situations and decide on possible responses.
in the cockpit typically results in plans that are always easy to modify when things are not as anticipated.
is unnecessary in the cockpit, as crew members are so highly trained, they will always know what to do in unusual situations.
is dangerous in the cockpit, as it interrupts flight crew creativity.

variant.question:

2-Waiting for an infrequent phenomenon  
3-Monitoring to ensure that certain values are not exceeded  
4-Detection of unusual conditions (smell, noise, etc.)
Ergonomics are associated with:

options.text: the human/workplace interface.
information processing.
communications.
cognition.

variant.question: When can a system be said to be tolerant to error? When:

options.text: the consequences of an error will not seriously jeopardize safety.
its safety system has taken account of all statistically probable errors.
latent errors do not entail serious consequences for safety.
its safety system is too permeable to error.

variant.question: When can a system be said to be tolerant to error? When:

options.text: the consequences of an error will not seriously jeopardise safety
latent errors do not entail serious consequences for safety
its safety system is too permeable to error
its safety system has taken account of all statistically probable errors

variant.question: In order to provide optimum human performance it is advisable to:

options.text: establish strategies for planning, automating and managing resources (in real time).
plan a maximum of objectives and non-automated actions.
avoid powerful behaviour expedient of automating tasks.
plan future actions and decisions at least a couple of days in advance.

variant.question: The three main sources of external error generation in the flight crew compartment are...

options.text: ergonomics, economics and the social environment.
an inappropriate cognitive style, economics and a lack of motivation.
improper technique, impulsiveness, and the physical environment.
economics, over-confidence and the social environment.

variant.question: What does error tolerance aim for?

options.text: Providing a margin so that any errors do not endanger the flight.
Providing a way to return to a safe situation following an error.
Providing a means to bring pilot's attention to the error quickly.
Providing automatic systems that prevent the pilot from making an error.

variant.question: What is the current approach to human error?

options.text: Realization that humans are fallible and that systems and procedures should be designed to minimize human error.
Realization that humans are fallible and that systems and procedures should be brought into line to prevent system, latent and procedural errors.
Realization that humans are infallible and that systems and procedures should be brought into line to prevent system/procedural errors.
Realization that humans are infallible and that systems and procedures should be designed to minimize human error.

variant.question: What is the current approach to human error?

options.text: Realisation that humans are fallible and that systems and procedures should be designed to minimise human error.
Realisation that humans are fallible and that systems and procedures should be brought into line to prevent system, latent and procedural errors.
Realisation that humans are infallible and that systems and procedures should be brought into line to prevent system/procedural errors.
Realisation that humans are infallible and that systems/procedures should be designed to minimise human error.

variant.question: Which of the following is an example for error generation in the cockpit caused by the social environment?

options.text: An inexperienced copilot flying with the head-of-training after just barely passing his last simulator check.
A warning light that is installed in a position outside of the view of the pilot.
A challenging personal situation such as a divorce or the death of a close relative.
The use of cheap, outdated or damaged equipment.

variant.question: What is the definition of error tolerance in error management strategies?

options.text: Error tolerance means minimizing the effects of errors by making a system as tolerant as possible towards errors.
Error tolerance means minimizing the probability that an error occurs and also minimizing the extent of an error.
Error tolerance means that it will be simple to reset a system back to a safe state (after error occurrence).
Error tolerance means avoiding errors.

variant.question: What is the definition of error tolerance in error management strategies?

options.text: Error tolerance means minimizing the effects of errors by making a system as tolerant as possible towards errors.
Error tolerance means that it will be easy to reset a system back to a safe state after the error has occured.
Error tolerance means avoiding errors in the first place.
Error tolerance means minimising the probabillity that an error will occur as well as minimising the extent of the error.

variant.question:
What methods can be used to combat human error?

1. Reducing error-prone mechanisms.2. Improving the way in which error is taken into account in training.3. Sanctions against the initiators of error.4. Improving error detection techniques.
The combination of correct statements is:

options.text: 1, 2 and 4
2, 3 and 4
1 and 2
3 and 4

variant.question: It is commonly accepted that human error cannot be eliminated completely. The efforts taken to reduce the chance for human error and mitigate its impact is known as “error management”. Which of the following are known error management strategies?

options.text: Error prevention, error reduction, error detection, error recovery, error tolerance
Skill-based error prevention, rule-based error prevention, knowledge-based error prevention, error education
Error analysis, error classification, error identification, error intolerance, human error training
Error identification, error analysis, error recovery, error tolerance, error management training

variant.question: If one error is allowed to effect a whole system, the system is described as

options.text: Vulnerable
Corrupted
Error-prone
Error tolerant

variant.question: What would be the priority aim in the design of man↔machine interfaces and in the creation of their application procedures for fighting problems associated with human error?

options.text: To reduce the risks of the appearance or non-detection of errors entailing serious consequences.
To put in place redundant alarm systems.
To eliminate the risk of latent errors occurrence.
To cater systematically for the consequences of errors in order to analyse their nature and modify ergonomic parameters.

variant.question: Among the external factors that may contribute to an error, cockpit noise and the restriction of the field of view due to windscreen design correspond to:

options.text: ergonomic factors.
social factors.
organisational factors.
psychobiological factors.

variant.question: To completely eliminate human errors is not possible. Error Management is the term used for the endeavours to reduce human error and its impact. Which of the following are known error-management strategies?

options.text: Error prevention, error reduction, error detection, error recovery, and error tolerance.
Error analysis, error classification, error identification, error intolerance, and human error training.
Error identification, error analysis, error recovery, error tolerance, and error management training.
Skill-based error prevention, rule-based error prevention, knowledge-based error prevention, and error education.

1 malfunction of technical systems

economics, ergonomics and insufficient care.

variant.question: Which of the following describes an external error generated in the flight crew compartment due to poor ergonomics?

options.text: Incorrect selection of the speed brake instead of flaps due to the proximity and similar design of the levers.
Accepting a shorter routing from ATC which, while saving fuel, causes the aircraft to be too high, leading to an unstable approach.
Unnecessary distractions caused by conversation regarding company politics, leading to a missed air traffic control instruction.
Failure to cross-check a performance calculation of another crew member after an unexpected operational change prior to departure.

variant.question: Which of the following describes an external error generated in the flight crew compartment due to poor ergonomics?

options.text: Incorrect selection of the speed brake instead of flaps due to the proximity and similar design of the levers.

Unnecessary distractions caused by conversation regarding company politics, leading to a missed air traffic control instruction
Accepting a shorter routing from ATC which, while saving fuel, causes the aircraft to be too high, leading to an unstable approach.

variant.question:
ENVIRONMENTAL CAPTURE is a term used to describe which of the following statements?
1) The tendency for a skill to be executed in an environment in which it is frequently exercised.
2) The tendency for a skill acquired in one aircraft type to be executed in a new aircraft type, even if it is inappropriate to do so.
3) The tendency for people to behave in different ways in different social situations.
4) The gaining of environmental skills.
The performance of the man machine system is above all:

options.text: a combination which is based on decreasing the pilot's workload and increasing his time for supervision.
a balanced combination between someone actively engaged in his work and automated systems which serve to control the pilots workload.
a combination which must make the pilot available for the sphere in which he is most qualified, namely checking departures from the normal operating range.
a combination in which the pilot must keep the main repetitive tasks and automated systems under his control in line with rule-based behaviour.

variant.question: What are the main advantages of the human over the machine?

options.text: Creativity, innovation, and aptitude to deal with novel situations.
Ability to recognize system failures and rectify them quicker than a machine.
Ability to recognize limits on systems being exceeded quicker than a machine and resolve the situation.
Logic and the use of human senses.

variant.question: Which of the following dangers is associated with anticipation of future actions?

options.text: Selection of unsuitable actions which have been planned in advance
Monotony and hypovigilance because of lack of workload
Cognitive saturation because of high planning workload
Poor synergy because of mental detachment of the Copilot

variant.question:
Which of the following is one of the major goals in the design of human-centred man-machine interfaces?
To ensure they are

options.text: Simple and make it unlikely for a human pilot or automated system to commit an error.
Durable and can eliminate automation errors during high-workload phases of flight.
Standardised across aircraft types to ensure that pilots are still familiar with the cockpit indications when flying a new aircraft type.
Complicated and can reduce errors to the minimum acceptable level.

variant.question: How can man cope with low error tolerant situations?

options.text: By constantly complying with cross-over verification procedures (cross monitoring).
By increasing error detection in all circumstances.
By generally avoiding situations in which tolerance to error is low.
By randomly applying a combination of optimum detection, warning and monitoring systems.

variant.question: The errors of a motor programme are

options.text: action slip and environmental capture (habituation).
confirmation error and error of commission.
habituation and error of commission.
action slip and confirmation bias.

variant.question: Which of the following human error rates can be described as pretty good realistic and pretty good, after methodical training?

options.text: 1 in 1 000 times.
1 in 10 times.
1 in 100 times.
1 in 10 000 times.

variant.question: Which of the following human error rates can be described as pretty good realistic and pretty good, after methodical training?

options.text: 1 in 1 000 times.
1 in 10 000 times.
1 in 10 times.

variant.question: What is an example of external error caused by economical reasons?

options.text: Pilots accepting a shorter ATC clearance. Upon arrival, they realise that they are too high and have an unstablised approach.
The pilots missing an ATC clerance because they are distracted by the cabin crew.
Challenging and changing weather.
Flight crew missing a checkist item during pre-flight preparation.

variant.question: Error tolerance, which is an error management strategy, aims at making...

options.text: the system better able to sustain itself despite error, e.g. by minimising the consequences of errors.
errors apparent as fast and as clearly as possible, thereby enabling recovery.
it easy to rapidly recover the system to its safe state after an error has been committed.
the system such that it minimises both the likelihood and the magnitude of the error.

variant.question:
Pre-thought action plans may be said to:
1) ease access to information which may be necessary.
2) sensitize and prepare for a possible situation to come.
3) be readily interchangeable and can therefore be reformulated at any time during the flight.
4) define a framework and a probable strategy for the encountered situation.
The combination of correct statements is:
Select the statement which does not apply to planning and anticipation of future actions.

options.text: Pilots planning most of their decisions in advance waste a lot of time and increase overall workload.
Rigid plans can lead to overlooking better solutions in unexpected situations.
Planning improves the quality of decisions which have to be made in high-workload periods of flight.
Planning bears a risk of “seeing” expected conditions despite the existence of abnormal situations.

options.text: Ergonomics, economics, social environment

variant.question: Which of the following is an example for error generation in the cockpit caused by ergonomics?

An inexperienced copilot flying with the head-of-training after just barely passing his last simulator check.

A company culture that calls for maximisation of payload by generally abandoning the carriage of extra fuel.

options.text: A company culture that calls for maximisation of payload by generally abandoning the carriage of extra fuel.
An airline within which most employees come from closed-culture countries.
A company within which the highest value is placed with passenger comfort, even at the expense of flight safety.
Night curfew on the home base which requires short turn-arounds to be made to complete the planned flights.
